thread.title: No, WikiLeaks Didn't Just Reveal That The Government Has Access To Your Secure Messaging Apps - BuzzFeed News
thread.title_full: No, WikiLeaks Didn't Just Reveal That The Government Has Access To Your Secure Messaging Apps - BuzzFeed News

author: Sheera Frenkel
title: No, WikiLeaks Didn't Just Reveal That The Government Has Access To Your Secure Messaging Apps - BuzzFeed News
text:
View this image › 
Reuters File Photo / Reuters 
ID: 10655645 SAN FRANCISCO — A misreading of new WikiLeaks documents published Tuesday morning led to mass panic over whether the CIA and allied intelligence organizations could hack into secure messaging apps trusted by millions of people across the world.
The claims were made off a cache of almost 9,000 documents and files that WikiLeaks said came from the CIA’s Center for Cyber Intelligence and allegedly detail how the CIA hacks into phones, laptops, and other connected devices. A number of news outlets reported that the documents revealed that Signal, WhatsApp, and other messaging apps that use high-level encryption to ensure that messages are sent and received safely had been compromised.
WikiLeaks #Vault7 confirms CIA can effectively bypass Signal + Telegram + WhatsApp + Confide encryption https://t.co/h5wzfrReyy
— WikiLeaks (@wikileaks) ID: 10655638 Cybersecurity experts, however, were quick to point out that the documents simply stated that if a phone was compromised — which is to say if the CIA hacked into the phone itself — any apps on that phone would no be longer secure. This is the equivalent of saying that if your house is broken into and bugged, whispering softly on your phone in your bedroom is not going to make that conversation secure.

PSA: This incorrectly implies CIA hacked these apps / encryption. But the docs show iOS/Android are what got hacked… https://t.co/iMhyPVD7kk
— Edward Snowden (@Snowden) ID: 10655718 In other news, if somebody looks over shoulder while you text somebody in Signal, your comms aren't secure. https://t.co/tPlBLg6pu6
— Rob Pegoraro (@robpegoraro) ID: 10655616 

That's not what it says. Not about Signal. If your phone is hacked, *nothing* is foolproof. Iphones are hardest to… https://t.co/qxfB53309q
— Zeynep Tufekci (@zeynep) ID: 10655617 

There isn't an encryption protocol in the world that will protect you if your phone/computer/device is compromised https://t.co/qsvkQOsXjR
— Greg Otto (@gregotto) ID: 10655620 The leak is the latest to become public by WikiLeaks, which has come under fire for failing to adequately redact certain documents and also for its role in the US election. Last year the group released thousands of emails detailing the communications of top Democratic Party leaders — which were widely believed to originate from a Russian government–sponsored hack . US intelligence agencies accused Russia of trying to meddle in the US elections and said WikiLeaks had assisted in that cause.
